text:
Quick thoughts on public opinion about Mueller report:

-Everyone wants it released.

-Views on Russia investigation have been mostly ossified. But it's worth noting that a lot of people have been totally tuned out. Biggest chance for movement is from what those people hear.

text: Ah, yeah, wasn't trying to imply disengagement exactly; more a lack of firm conclusions. (although judging from name ID, etc., there is also a huge swath of the electorate that really hasn't started thinking about it much!)
author: aedwardslevy

text: Anyways, the point is that we have historical precedent and fundamentals and early fundraising numbers to talk about, but at a basic level...it's extremely difficult to predict what voters will do a year from now when most voters have no idea what they will do a year from now.

text: Quick note about Emerson Polling, since I don't know if everyone is aware: unlike other university polls (Monmouth/Qpac/Marist/etc), it is largely student-run. It also uses different methodology than most university polls (automated calls/online, rather than live callers).

text: Also, FWIW, the answers to that first question of where people see Trump's tweets are generally similar regardless of 2016 vote.
author: aedwardslevy

text:
On the left, Trump's highest-rated three tweets among Republicans, per YouGov's tracking (all military related). On the right, the lowest-rated (attacks on Mark Cuban, Schwarzenegger, Mika Brzezinski). 

https://tweetindex.yougov.com/?sort=rep
author: aedwardslevy

text: Also worth noting, per that post, that even Trump's supporters prefer his anodyne tweets over personal attacks. E.g. from last fall: 69% of Republicans thought Trump wishing the Navy a happy birthday was a "great" tweet. 41% said the same about him calling Warren "Pocahontas."

text: Another GSS datapoint: In 2018, just 13% of Americans said men were better suited for politics than women were, a record low. https://gssdataexplorer.norc.org/trends/Politics

text: I talk a lot about not overemphasizing small fluctuations in trend data, and one of the reasons why is this: when there's a significant shift like the recent change on racial attitudes, it is often Really Obvious.
author: aedwardslevy

text:
In 2014, 40% of non-black Dems said black Americans' disadvantage in jobs/income/housing compared to whites is mainly due to discrimination. In 2018, 59% say the same.

Independents and GOP moved in the same direction, but less steeply.
